There are no such things as jelly fish. Actually they are properly called sea jellies! Fish have eyes, scales, fins, bones, cartilage, and a bilateral body plan. Sea jellies have no scales, no fins, tentacles, no bones, no spinal chord, and are in no way fish.

Shot in the dark of the abyss, but the isopod is probably a psuedo-helper/parasite for the jellyfish that acts as a lure to attract prey, similar to the crustacean that attaches itself to the eyes of sleeper sharks. The jellyfish is likely transparent to the eyes of deep sea animals, but the isopod is probably very visible and looks like an unsuspecting prey item. A hunting fish or squid will dash at the isopod for an easy meal and hit the jellyfish's stinging bell instead, turning the hunter into the hunted. Once the jellyfish had pulled the paralyzed prey into its mouth they both eat the catch, but the isopod probably steals most of it due to having more complex mouthparts. Eventually though, both will get enough to eat and the jellyfish will make more kills with a parasitic partner rather than waiting for something to just swim into it by accident.
